Review Interfacial design of silicon/carbon anodes for rechargeable batteries: A review Quanyan Man a c Yongling An a Chengkai Liu a Hengtao Shen a Shenglin Xiong b Jinkui Feng a c ⁎ a Key Laboratory for Liquid-Solid Structural Evolution & Processing of Materials (Ministry of Education), School of Materials Science and Engineering, Shandong University, Jinan 250061, Shandong, China Key Laboratory for Liquid-Solid Structural Evolution & Processing of Materials (Ministry of Education) School of Materials Science and Engineering Shandong University Jinan 250061 Shandong China Key Laboratory for Liquid-Solid Structural Evolution & Processing of Materials (Ministry of Education), School of Materials Science and Engineering, Shandong University, Jinan 250061, Shandong, China b School of Chemistry and Chemical Engineering, Shandong University, Jinan 250100, Shandong, China School of Chemistry and Chemical Engineering Shandong University Jinan 250100 Shandong China School of Chemistry and Chemical Engineering, Shandong University, Jinan 250100, Shandong, China c Shenzhen Institute of Shandong University, Shenzhen 518057, Guangdong, China Shenzhen Institute of Shandong University Shenzhen 518057 China Shenzhen Institute of Shandong University, Shenzhen 518057, Guangdong, China ⁎ Corresponding author. Graphical abstract In this review, we focus on traditional carbon sources (graphite, etc.), and novel carbon sources (MXene, graphene, etc.). The merits and demerits of interfacial bonding of Si/C composites are summarized. Silicon (Si) has been studied as a promising alloying type anode for lithium-ion batteries due to its high specific capacity, low operating potential and abundant resources. Nevertheless, huge volume expansion during alloying/dealloying processes and low electronic conductivity of Si anodes restrict their electrochemical performance. Thus, carbon (C) materials with special physical and chemical properties are applied in Si anodes to effectively solve these problems. This review focuses on current status in the exploration of Si/C anodes, including the lithiation mechanism and solid electrolyte interface formation, various carbon sources in Si/C anodes, such as traditional carbon sources (graphite, pitch, biomass), and novel carbon sources (MXene, graphene, MOFs-derived carbon, graphdiyne, etc.), as well as interfacial bonding modes of Si and C in the Si/C anodes. Finally, we summarize and prospect the selection of carbonaceous materials, structural design and interface control of Si/C anodes, and application of Si/C anodes in all-solid-state lithium-ion batteries and sodium-ion batteries et al. This review will help researchers in the design of novel Si/C anodes for rechargeable batteries. Keywords Silicon/carbon anodes Lithium-ion batteries Interfacial reaction Carbon sources Interface bonding 1 Introduction Lithium-ion batteries (LIBs) have been used in electrombiles and portable electronics on account of seductive energy and power densities [1–4]. As market places higher demand on the energy density of LIBs, it is difficult for commercial graphitic carbon anodes to meet this demand due to their low specific capacity [5]. Therefore, Silicon (Si) is a candidate as anode for next-generation LIBs since its high specific capacity, low operating potential and abundant reserves [6–9]. Nevertheless, Si has a huge volume expansion (>300%) during alloying/dealloying, which will bring about pulverization and electrical contact loss of Si anodes. In addition, such huge volume changes also will induce repeated rupture and growth of the solid electrolyte interface (SEI) which consumes many electrolytes. Consequently, bulk Si has poor cycling stability and low coulombic efficiencies [10,11]. Structural design such as nanoparticles [12], nanosheets [13–15] and nanoporous structures [16–18] is reported as an efficacious method to alleviate enormous volume expansion of Si anodes. When used as LIBs anodes, the Si nanostructures achieved improved cycle life compared to the bulk Si [16,19]. However, Si nanostructures have large specific surface area (SSA) which enlarges the electrode/electrolyte interfacial area, resulting in a low initial Coulombic efficiency (ICE), generally 60%–80% [13,14,17]. In addition, pure Si has low electronic conductivity, which is not conducive to electrochemical processes [20]. Accordingly, various composite materials of carbon materials and Si have been developed, and the carbon coating can improve structural stability of Si and SEI [8,21–23]. As shown in Fig. 1 , there has been a high level of interest in silicon-carbon (Si/C) composites over the past decade, with an average of no more than 100 papers published per year before 2011, and more than 500 papers per year in 2019–2021. In addition, the number of citations in 2021 is as high as 29,800. In brief, the improved electrochemical performance of Si/C composites is mainly attributed to splendid properties of carbon, rational structural design and synergistic effect between multiple components [24–26]. Several reviews focused on Si/C composites have been published recently [25–29]. Based on structure of the Si/C composites, Zhang et al. [29] systematically compared electrochemical properties of Si/C composites from zero-dimension (0D) to three-dimension (3D). The merits and demerits of various structures of Si/C composites were analyzed. This review provides a reference for developing optimal structural designs for Si/C composites. Rümmeli et al. [26] described in detail the Si/C composites constructed with one-dimension (1D), two-dimension (2D), and 3D carbon materials and Si, and used several advanced characterization techniques to further explain the excellent properties of Si/C composites. Guo et al. [25] reviewed the effects of parameters, such as carbonaceous materials, structures, synthesis techniques and processing methods, on electrochemical properties of Si/G/C composites. This review provided a guidance on selection and synthesis of carbonaceous materials. These recent reviews mainly provided a detailed summary and outlook from the aspects of different dimensional structural design and in-situ characterization of Si/C composites. Therefore, it is essential to write an up-to-date review which summarizes the latest development about carbon sources for Si/C composites and interface bonding between Si and C. As shown in Fig. 2 , this review first reviews two interfacial reactions of Si anodes, including alloying and SEI formation. And we categorize carbon sources for Si/C composites into five categories, including graphite, new carbon materials (MXene, graphene, graphdiyne etc.), macromolecular compound-derived carbons, biomass-derived nanostructured carbons and carbonaceous gas-derived carbons. The merits and demerits of each type of carbon sources are summarized. In addition, this paper also pays attention to the research on interfacial bonding of Si/C composites in recent years. This review will provide some references for the selection of carbon sources and interface designs in Si/C composites. 2 Interfacial reaction of Si/C anodes Interface reaction of Si/C anodes includes the lithiation/delithiation process and SEI formation. 2.1 Lithiation/delithiation of Si/C anodes The lithiation/delithiation process is the most important interface reaction of the Si/C anodes, and it is also the principal reason for the failure of Si/C anodes [41–43]. In-depth understanding of lithiation/delithiation process can effectively guide structural design and interface modification of Si/C anodes. 2.1.1 Electrochemical process In Si/C anodes, lithiation and delithiation behaviors of Si and C as separate components have been proved [44,45]. For example, Cheng et al. [45] studied the lithiation and delithiation process of Si NP-filled CNT. During lithiation, Li+ transport was divided into three steps. First, the CNTs were lithiated and a SEI layer was formed on the outer surface of CNTs. Second, Li+ penetrate carbon layer and enter the interior of CNTs. Third, Li+ were easily transported to Si NPs through the CNT/Si NP interface by surface diffusion. Besides, Wang et al. [44] investigated lithiation behavior of SiNPs attached on and embedded in carbon nanofibers. SiNPs embedded in carbon exhibited delayed lithiation compared to surface-attached SiNPs. The alloying reaction of Si and Li is described as: Si + x Li+ + xe− ↔ Li x Si The electrochemical alloying of Si and Li followed the Li-Si phase diagram at 415 °C (Fig. 3 a and b). This process formed four phases of Li2Si7, Li7S3, Li13Si4, and Li22Si5, corresponding to voltage platforms of 0.332, 0.288, 0.158 and 0.044 V, respectively [11]. However, lithiation of Si at room temperature deviates from equilibrium state. Si shows a low voltage platform around 0.1 V in initial discharge curve, due to the coexistence of both c-Si and a-Li x Si [46]. When voltage drops below 50 mV, a-Li x Si suddenly converts to c-Li3.75Si. In addition, the lithiation curves of the subsequent cycles process have no voltage platform and present a round-shaped. During delithium process, c-Li3.75Si converts to a-Li x Si and then to a-Si. During the next charging process, a-Si still remains in amorphous [46]. Grey et al. [47] studied lithiation and delithiation behaviors of Si nanowires (SiNWs) by 7Li in-situ NMR spectroscopy. When SiNWs was discharged (current C/25, voltage range 0–2 V), four distinct processes could be observed. At ∼300–250 mV, a-Si lattice gradually lithiated into Li∼2.0Si, which included Si network and Si–Si clusters. At 100 mV, the stage formed Li∼3.5Si, which was attributed to cleavage of Si–Si bonds, forming Si clusters and ultimately insulated Si anions. At 50 mV, equaled to c-Li3.75Si formation. At <30 mV, there was an excessive ver-lithiated phase, c-Li3.75+ δ Si. 2.1.2 Morphological evolution During initial lithiation process, c-Si facing the lithium electrode gradually transformed into a-Li x Si with a moving phase boundary. The phase boundary thickness was observed to be ∼1 nm by high-resolution transmission electron microscope (TEM) [48,52]. Moreover, the reaction rate of this phase interface determined lithiation speed of Si [48,53]. For a-Li x Si, when x was less than or close to 3.75, its composition was homogeneous, free of crystalline phases. With further lithiation, the entire Si nanowire transformed into c-Li15Si4 without chemical composition fluctuations. This transition was just a local rearrangement of the atomic configuration. It was caused by electrochemically driven Li directional diffusion, a process known as “electrochemically driven congruent crystallization” [48]. During lithiation, a biaxial compressive stress of ca. 0.5 GPa was generated in amorphous layer, which converted into tensile stress during delithiation. Amorphous area commenced to undergo plastic deformation at about 0.5 GPa. As lithiation progresses, the increasing stress caused amorphous layer to break into micro fragments, and the cracks extended into crystalline Si [52]. Previous reports have shown that the expansion of Si has a certain orientation [49,53,54]. Cui et al. [49] investigated the morphology of vertical Si nanopillars with 〈100〉, 〈110〉, and 〈111〉 axial orientations when they were initial lithiated. In this work, pristine Si nanopillars have circular cross-sections. 〈100〉, 〈110〉, and 〈111〉 nanopillars were transformed into a cross, an ellipse, and a hexagon, respectively (Fig. 3c). It was obvious that the nanometer pillars deformed most distinctly in 〈110〉 direction. 〈110〉 is a prominent ion implantation channel, because along 〈110〉 direction, c-Si has larger spaces between atoms, much larger than 〈100〉 and 〈111〉 directions. Nevertheless, during lithiation, the polycrystalline Si exhibited ∼270% volume change with ∼55% expansion in each orthotropic direction [53]. Si/C anodes showed distinct laws of volume expansion and mechanisms of stress release on account of carbon existence. Park et al. [55] studied structural deformation of 2DSi@C in initial two charging/discharging process. carbon layer forcefully restricted lateral expansion of 2DSi. This caused enormous anisotropic expansion of fully lithiated 2DSi@C, with ∼9.7% expansion in lateral directions, but ∼200% in thickness direction. Due to the limiting influence of carbon layer, high compressive stress was created inside the lithiated 2DSi, which restrained crack formation and spread. During delithiation, 2DSi@C formed highly expanded crinkle structures that relieved internal stress in 2DSi. The fracture pulverization caused by the volume expansion of Si anodes is an important problem that limits its application [33,43,56]. The crack generation of Si particles has a strong size dependence. Huang et al. [50] applied in-situ TEM to dynamically explore lithiation behaviors of different direct Si nanoparticles. The study found that when particle size is less than 150 nm, there will be no cracks even with huge volume expansion (Fig. 3d). When particle size is larger than 150 nm, Si nanoparticle first generates cracks on the surface, and the cracks rapidly expand inward when the lithiation continues. At the same time, more cracks appeared in different positions. Eventually, the Si particles were broken and pulverized. The surface fracture of Si nanoparticles larger than 150 nm in size due to tensile stress exceeding yield strength during lithiation. Therefore, designing nanoscale Si anodes is an important strategy to maintain cycling stability of LIBs [57–59]. When a carbon layer is introduced to Si anode, the fracture of Si is not only related to the size but also to the properties of carbon. Seeking new quantitative parameters is helpful to design high performance Si/C anodes. Yao et al. [51] studied in-situ lithiation of carbon-coated Si nanoparticles (Si@C NPs). In this work, Si@C NPs smaller than 150 nm fractured during lithiation. Finite element analysis showed that material inhomogeneity caused by fractured carbon coating would induce cracks into SiNPs. The fracture of Si@C NPs was related to the diameter of Si core (D) and thickness of carbon coating (t). Normalized σ max FL (maximum tensile stress of carbon coating when fully lithiated) as a function of D and t showed that all Si@C NPs fractured when D/t was greater than 7, and when the D/t was less than 3.5, Si@C NPs did not fracture (Fig. 3e). Larger D and smaller t resulted in higher σ max FL . In order to prevent the cracking of carbon coating, σ max FL should be smaller than σ f (breaking strength of carbon). For a given σ f , the “unimpaired region” on the D-t plane ensured the integrity of carbon coating. 2.2 Formation of SEI on Si/C anodes SEI plays a crucial role in Si anodes for LIBs, such as limiting further reaction of electrode with electrolyte and forming stable Li ions channels [60,61]. To study Si/C anodes, it is required to fully comprehend SEI formation. Electrochemical window of electrolyte is energy interval E g of the highest occupied molecular orbital (HOMO) and lowest unoccupied molecular orbital (LUMO) of the electrolyte. Since the electrolyte window is not wide enough, solvent and lithium salt will be reduced or oxidized during charging and discharging process. Consequently, insoluble deposits will be formed on the electrode surface to form SEI (Fig. 4 a) [62]. Since SEI generated on surface is composed of electrolyte decomposition products, different electrolytes have a considerable effect on composition and stability of SEI. Lucht et al. [63] used HAXPES to study SEI evolution of Si nanoparticles cycled in different electrolytes. For LiPF6 in EC electrolyte, the SEI mainly consisted of lithium ethylene dicarbonate (LEDC), LiF, a small amount of Li2CO3 and lithium salts. After first cycle, LEDC dominated external SEI and concentration of LiF increased in internal SEI. After cycling, concentrations of C, O, and F did not change. However, the LEDC decomposed into carbon dioxide, lithium oxalate, Li2CO3, and lithium alkoxide, indicating the SEI was not stable in cycling process. Si-containing species mixed with SEI were dominated by the outer SiO2 and the inner Li x SiO y without the composition of the Si component change during cycling. For ethylene carbonate (EC): fluoroethylene carbonate (FEC) electrolyte, SEI also contained LEDC, LiF and poly (FEC). Compared with EC electrolyte, concentration of LiF was higher in outer SEI and lower in inner SEI. As cycle progresses, the concentration of F increases. Moreover, the internal LEDC did not decompose, indicating that presence of poly (FEC) and LiF inhibited decomposition of LEDC during cycling. The Si-containing species of SEI were similar to those in EC electrolytes, consisting of SiO2 on the outside and Li x SiO y on the inside. However, SEI formed in EC:FEC electrolyte was slightly thinner than that formed in EC electrolyte because of the greater depth of Li x Si in EC:FEC electrolyte (Fig. 4b). Xu et al. [64] prepared hept-carbon-coated SiNPs (Hept-SiNP) with a complete carbon layer during lithiation/delithiation process. The composition of SEI was investigated by In-depth X-ray photoelectric spectroscopy (XPS). Before sputtering, Hept-SiNP anodes demonstrated ordinary decomposition products of organic solvent molecules. With the sputtering of Hept-SiNPs from 50 to 600 s, LiF band intensity gradually decreased, while the Si and Li x Si intensities increased. This finding indicated the existence of a thin SEI layer and efficient separation of Si and SEI by a carbon coating (Fig. 4c). However, when the carbon layer couldn’t protect Si anodes, the electrolyte would react with Si to form SEI components such as Li4SiO4 (Fig. 4d). 3 Sources of carbon in Si/C anodes Plentiful carbon sources and preparation methods of Si/C composites give them distinct electrochemical properties [25,65]. In this paper, carbon sources of Si/C composites are divided into graphite, new carbon materials, macromolecular compound-derived carbons, biomass-derived nanostructured carbons and carbonaceous gas-derived carbons depending on whether pyrolysis is required. 3.1 Graphite Graphite is a commercialized anode of LIBs on account of its low cost, excellent stability and high conductivity [66,67]. Nevertheless, the theoretical capacity of graphite is merely 372 mAh/g, limited by inherent combination of six carbon atoms and merely-one lithium atom, which can no longer meet the needs for the development of high energy density energy storage systems [5]. In the past years, Si/graphite has attracted many researchers on account of its high tap density and stable physical/chemical properties [68,69]. Wetjen et al. [70] prepared silicon-graphite (SiG) electrodes composed of physical mixtures of different Si/G ratios with Si contents between 20–60 wt% (Fig. 5 a). The Capacity retentions of different electrodes were between 82% (20 wt% Si) and 67% (60 wt% Si) after 120 cycles in SiG//LFP coin-cells (Fig. 5b). Nevertheless, all electrodes displayed very similar ICE (85%–88%). This may be attributed to that SEI formation process was comparable at G and Si. It is arduous to construct stable composites with Si due to very stable chemical properties of graphite. Therefore, the electrochemical performance of electrode prepared by mechanical ball milling of graphite and Si is not satisfactory. Improving stress distribution and cycling performance by designing structure or introducing other materials is a feasible approach [68]. For example, Using Al-Si alloy and graphite flakes as raw materials, Han et al. [71] designed a chessboard-like Si/graphite anode by combination of calcination and etching. The optimized composition of c-Gr + 15% Si composite provided 485.3 mAh/g and 92.9% capacity retention after 400 cycles at 1 A/g. Constructing 3D structure electrodes is an effective method to reduce mechanical tension. Zheng et al. [72] produced silicon/graphite (Si/C) composites with free-standing structures by ultrafast laser ablation. Ultrafast laser processing could ablate precisely, reducing the width of channels down to 20 nm. The structured Si/C electrode exhibited higher specific capacities at different currents compared to unstructured electrode (reference). The coulombic efficiency of different C-rates stayed between 96.4% and 99.82%. For unstructured electrode, its coulombic efficiency was higher than 100%, and large scattering occurred at high C-rates. Furthermore, structured Si/C electrode showed stable cyclic performance. The excellent property may be ascribed to improved Li+ diffusion overpotential, reduction of dynamic interfaces during alloying, and artificial voids. Carbonaceous additives can endow Si/G composites good structural stability. Cho et al. [39] employed mechanical agitation and chemical vapor deposition methods to synthesize a Si-graphite anode with calendaring-compatible macroporous structure (C/Si@MPC-G) (Fig. 5c). The anode was formed of a graphite core, a nonfilling porous architecture and an elastic outermost carbon covering from inner to outer (Fig. 5d and e). As anodes for LIBs, the C/Si@MPC-G composites exhibited a 95.6% capacity retention at 0.5 C after 50 cycles with excellent ICE of 90.9% in a half-cell (Fig. 5f). In addition, the anode showed high volumetric energy density of 932 Wh/L specific energy of 333 Wh/kg. The superior electrochemical property of C/Si@MPC-G composite could be ascribed to the introduction of macroporous carbon matrix on the composite and the surface area consistenting with conventional synthetic graphite. Graphite has natural advantages as a carbon source due to its stable physical and chemical properties and low price [73,74]. However, contact between graphite and Si is not stable enough, and it is difficult to achieve ideal cycle stability through simple blending [70]. Therefore, further practical researches need to introduce other modification methods [25,32,75]. 3.2 New carbon-based nanomaterials New carbon materials such as graphene, carbon nanotubes, and graphdiyne have acquired widespread attention due to their low density, high strength, fatigue resistance, chemical resistance, and excellent electrical conductivity. As a result, the introduction of new carbon materials into LIBs to improve interfacial stability of Si anodes is a research hotspot [34,76–78]. 3.2.1 Carbon nanotubes Carbon nanotubes are often applied as additives to enhance electrochemical performance of electrodes due to its high conductivity, excellent aspect ratio and tortuosity [27,32,77,79]. So, combining carbon nanotubes and Si would be a reasonable strategy. Li et al. [80] used ZIF-67 as precursor and obtained Si@N-doped CNTs (Fig. 6 a). The composite material was composed of a three-dimensional porous conductive network formed by N-doped CNTs, which were uniformly distributed on surface of Si particles (Fig. 6b). Brunner-Emmet-Teller (BET) test showed that the SSA of composite was 341.0 m2/g. As shown in Fig. 6(c), the composite material provided 1100 mAh/g capacity after 700 cycles. The remarkable performance of Si@N-doped CNTs was attributed to cross-linked n-doped carbon nanotube network with elevated conductivity and flexibility, buffering stress and volume expansion. With the excellent mechanical properties of CNTs, CNTs can be used to build Si/C anodes with superior mechanical strength. Zhang et al. [81] fabricated a CNT@Si@C with a low expansion of ∼40% when fully lithiated. Under similar electrode loading (0.75 mAh/cm2), the cycling stability of CNT@Si@C was much better than nano-Si and micro-Si. CNT@Si@C had a >87% capacity retention after ∼1500 cycles. After increasing the electrode loading, CNT@Si@C could still provide remarkable cycling stability. When the practical load was 3 mAh/cm2, the electrode still retained 90% capacity after 100 cycles. 3.2.2 Carbon fiber Carbon fiber has splendid properties such as high axial strength, fatigue resistance, corrosion resistance, and good electrical conductivity [78,82]. The application of carbon fiber in the battery has advantages unmatched by other materials. Kim et al. [83] proposed to prepare Si nanoparticles embedded into N-doped carbon nanofibers (w-Si@N-CNFs) by electrospinning and carbonization (800 °C). In this process, polyethylene glycol (PEG) was used as a dispersion agent to prevent the agglomeration of Si nanoparticles. Thus, Si nanoparticles are uniformly distributed on carbon fibers without agglomeration. As anode materials for LIBs, w-Si@N-CNF anode delivered the reversible capacities of 500 mAh/g at 4000 mA/g, which was much higher than the Si nanoparticles embedded into N-doped carbon nanofibers without PEG (wo-Si@N-CNF). The reason for enhanced electrochemical performance was further explained by Nyquist plots and electrochemical impedance spectroscopy (EIS) spectra. After 5 and 20 cycles, the charge-transfer resistance (R ct) of w-Si@N-CNF was 5.9 and 4.6 Ω, respectively. Yet, R ct of wo-Si@N-CNF reached 6.9 and 10.9 Ω. Consequently, carbon fibers encapsulated the dispersed Si nanoparticles, which was beneficial to forming stable SEI and buffering volume change of Si. Flexible electrodes are important components in wearable devices [84], In addition, carbon fibers with superior mechanical properties and electrical conductivity are important carbon sources for constructing flexible Si/C anodes. Wang et al. [33] fabricated a binder-free, flexible electrode formed by cross-linking of self-assembled silicon nanodot (SHC) microspheres and nitrogen-doped carbon fibers (SHCM/NCF) (Fig. 6d). The SHCM/NCF anodes demonstrated a 1442 mAh/g capacity after 800 cycles at 1 A/g in half-cell. The introduction of carbon fiber was advantageous to inhibit side reactions and ensure stable electrical contact (Fig. 6e). Furthermore, self-assembled Si nanodot microspheres improved the structural stability and tap density. These various designs realized the excellent electrochemical performance of SHCM/NCF (Fig. 6f). 3.2.3 Graphene Graphene is an important choice for compounding with Si due to its huge SSA, high electrical conductivity, and impressive mechanical strength [85–87]. In recent years, a large number of studies on Si/graphene composites have been reported [88–91]. Various novel structural design strategies such as cladding [88], supported [35], and core-shell structures [22,76] have been studied. Further, different fabrication approaches have also been used to prepare Si/graphene composite materials such as ball-milling [92–94], sol-gel method [95] and chemical vapor deposition (CVD) [22,96,97]. For instance, Yang et al. [93] fabricated Si/graphene composites using functionalization-assistant ball milling. The introduced –NH2 and –COOH formed covalent bonds between Si and graphene, thus solving the problems of poor dispersion and weak connection. As anodes of LIBs, the composite material demonstrated excellent cycling stability and superior rate performance. Controlling space between graphene and Si is effective in accommodating the volume expansion of Si and stable SEI formation. Graphene coating can be easily fabricated by CVD. Cui et al. [22] coated Ni on Si microparticles (SiMP) as catalyst for graphene growth and template for providing void spaces to synthesize graphene-encapsulated SiMP. Graphene cage acted as strong buffer that allowed SiMP to expand and fracture within it, and could ensure electrical connection between SiMP and electrodes. In addition, graphene was chemically inert, so that stable SEI was formed on the graphene cage, reducing unconsumable Li+. The reversible capacity of graphene-encapsulated SiMP at 0.05 C (1 C = 4.2 A/g) reached ∼3300 mAh/g. In subsequent cycles, the capacity retention rate was over 85% at 0.5 C current density for 300 cycles. Lu et al. [76] synthesized mesoporous Si spheres encapsulated by N-doped graphene cages (denoted as Si@graphene cage) as LIBs anodes through magnesium thermal reduction reaction and scalable CVD process (Fig. 7 a). The by-product of magnesium thermal reduction served as template and catalyst. Si@graphene cage showed high specific capacity, and excellent rate performance (Fig. 7b). When paired with LiCoO2 cathode, it obtained high energy density of 329 Wh/kg. Three-dimensional nanostructures are extensively applied in the construction of electrode materials [98–100]. Chen et al. [101] designed a porous N-doped graphene@Si@hybrid silicate (N-G@Si@HSi) free-standing and stackable anode. Nanoporous graphene was used as a flexible conductive framework and ionically conductive hybrid silicate was used as a shell to enhance flexibility and robustness of built three-dimensional nanostructures, which was conducive to preventing electrolyte infiltration into the Si layer and regulating the growth of SEI. Porous N-G@Si@HSi displayed superior rate capability and cycling performance on account of rational structural design. 3.2.4 Graphdiyne It is generally difficult to construct graphene or carbon nanotube-Si composites in-situ because the growth of graphene and carbon nanotubes needs to be carried out at high temperature [90]. Graphdiyne (GDY) is a 2D carbon allotrope that is prepared under a mild condition in solution [102,103]. Extensive theoretical calculations have shown that it has excellent electrical conductivity and mechanical properties, as well as a three-dimensional Li+ transport channel [104,105]. These characteristics make graphdiyne one of the important carbon materials to solve problem in Si anodes. For example, Li et al. [34] constructed all-carbon graphdiyne in-situ on Si anode at ultralow temperature (25 °C). The composite had a well-voided three-dimensional all-carbon conductive network and robust interfacial contact between electrode components (Fig. 7c). It could effectively alleviate degradation of the conductive network and interfacial contact problems caused by repeated volume changes (Fig. 7d). When used as anode for LIBs, it showed outstanding rate stability (1988 mAh/g was still remained at 10 A/g) and cycling performance (1503 mAh/g after 1450 cycles). 3.2.5 MXene MXene was compounded by Gogotsi et al. in 2011 [106]. Due to its high conductivity [107], strong mechanical properties [31,108,109] and abundant functional groups [110,111], MXene-based materials have been used in electrocatalysis [112,113], electromagnetic shielding [114–116] and energy storage [21,31,117,118]. In recent years, combining MXene and Si-based materials have attracted many researchers [31,109,119,120]. In 2019, our group [109] designed flexible, and freestanding Si/MXene composite papers through vacuum filtration (Fig. 8 a–c). In this work, MXene acted as conductive agent and current collector, which could prevent aggregation of Si particles and suppress the stress accumulation of Si during cycling. When used as anodes for LIBs, Si/MXene composites exhibited improved rate capability and long-cycling performance (Fig. 8d). Regulating empty space to accommodate volume change of Si in MXene should be considered. Fan et al. [121] fabricated sandwich-like Si/d-Ti3C2 hybrids with various mass ratios by TMAOH delamination and freeze-drying. As the Si mass ratio decreased, Si/d-Ti3C2 hybrids exhibited reduced capacity and improved cycling stability. This phenomenon indicated that introduction of MXene was beneficial to enhancing structural stability and electronic conductivity of electrodes, but excessive introduction of low-capacity MXene will reduce the specific capacity of electrodes. Si/d-Ti3C2 hybrids (2:1) showed the best cycling performance (1137.6 mAh/g at 500 mA/g after 200 cycles) and rate capability (890 mAh/g at 2 A/g). To enable ordered assembly of MXene and Si, the synthesis process was aided by surfactants. Song et al. [122] achieved dual MXene protection of Si nanoparticles (SiNPs@MX1/MX2) by electrostatic force induction, hydrothermal reaction and freeze-drying. The MX1 coating could avoid the agglomeration of SiNPs and alleviate the volume expansion, and the MX2 coating allowed fast electron and ion transport. The synergistic effect of the double coating constructed a stable SEI. Benefiting from its unique structural design, it exhibited excellent property when used as anodes for LIBs. Constructing stable and continuous SEI on surface of Si anodes is key to realizing high cycling stability. Numerous studies have shown that the electrode–electrolyte interface can be improved by modifying the interface of Si with MXene. Yang et al. [31] reported a Si-based composite (Si p-NSs@TNSs) with MXene nanosheets (TNSs) coated with Si porous nanospheres (Si p-NSs) through an interfacial assembly process (Fig. 8e). In this work, TNSs could prevent the contact of electrolyte with Si p-NSs, provide strong transport interfaces, and adapt to expansion of Si p-NSs (Fig. 8g–i). Additionally, abundant functional groups on the surface of TNSs could form Si–O–Ti bonds with –OH groups on the Si surface, which was beneficial to enhance interfacial electron transfer and improve cycling stability (Fig. 8f). Furthermore, the study by Yang et al. [108] showed that abundant –F of MXene nanosheets facilitate in-situ formation of compact and mechanically strong LiF-rich SEI during cycling, which not only prevented secondary reaction between Si and organic electrolyte but also improved the structural stability of the MXene framework. To improve practical application of MXene-based composites, Yan et al. [123] reported Ti3C2T x /Si composite scrolls via cold quenching in liquid nitrogen and rolling process. When content of Si is 10%, Ti3C2T x /Si composite scrolls showed superior cycle life and rate performance. The new carbon materials have excellent mechanical and electrochemical properties [34,77,124,125]. The above-mentioned Si/C composites using graphene, carbon nanotubes, carbon fibers, etc. as carbon sources through rational structural design obtain ultra-long cycle stability, showing the great potential for application in LIBs [76,81]. However, the preparation process of graphene, carbon nanotubes, etc. is relatively complex, which is challenging in large-scale production. Although there are commercial new carbon materials, they are expensive and difficult to commercialize in Si/C composites [25]. 3.3 Macromolecular compound-derived carbons As one of the most economical pyrolytic carbon precursors, macromolecular compound, such as polyvinyl pyrrolidone (PVP), polydopamine (PDA), pitch etc., are widely used in Si/C composites. Macromolecular compound-derived carbons have certain elasticity, which can buffer repeated expansion of Si anode. They also have strong connection between the interfaces, which can fix Si in conductive network [38,126–128]. 3.3.1 Pitch Petroleum-derived pitch is the source of carbon coatings for conventional graphite anodes and an important precursor for synthesis of carbon fibers and graphite. However, the factors that lead to the superior mechanical properties of pitch-derived carbons have not been fully investigated. Cho et al. [65] achieved a uniform pitch-derived carbon coating on Si nanolayer-embedded graphite (SG) by simply mixing SG, pitch and tetrahydrofuran, and then carbonizing at 900 °C under inert atmosphere. Pitch-coated Si nanoparticles did not expand significantly during lithiation. But acetylene carbon shell was easily broken under the same conditions. When bias of electrodes increased to −7 V, pitch-coated SiNPs expanded by 20%, which was much less than 60% when Si nanoparticles were fully lithiated. Further, although the pitch-coated Si nanoparticles expanded, no cracks occurred. Impressively, SGCpitch had 81.9% capacity retention after 200 cycles with industrial electrode density (1.6 g/cc). The excellent property was ascribed to superior mechanical properties of Cpitch, which could accommodate repeated expansion of Si and reduce electrode interface side reactions. Porous Si/C composites are widely used as high-performance anodes for LIBs [81,129,130]. Impregnation of carbon-containing precursors into nanovoids remains challenging. Zhang et al. [38] prepared micrometer-sized Np-Si with large SSA (972 m2/g) and small pore sizes (<4 nm) through heat treatment and chemical etching process. Petroleum pitch dissolved in toluene was used as a carbon source, and PC/Np-Si was obtained through electrostatic interaction and carbonization at 700 °C (Fig. 9 a–d). As anode materials for LIBs, PC/Np-Si displayed 90% capacity retention after 50 cycles with little loss of capacity after the 10th cycle in half cell. Introduction of petroleum pitch into Np-Si not only built a carbon layer that buffered volume change of Si alloying process but also prevented sintering of Si and shrinkage of nanopores at high temperatures, thereby realizing highly practical Si/C composites. Our group [131] synthesized porous Si@C by vacuum distillation using commercial Mg2Si alloys and pitch as precursors. The degree of graphitization of carbon was high due to the catalytic effect of metallic magnesium formed in-situ from Mg2Si alloys. Since porous structure could suppress volume change of Si, and carbon coating had good electrical conductivity, pSi@C exhibited improved lithium storage capacity. In mixTHF, the reversible discharge capacity of pSi@C was 309.5 mAh/g. 3.3.2 Heteroatom polymer Heteroatoms are found in many polymers, of which nitrogen is the most commonly studied [132]. Heteroatoms have an effect of electron imbalance and can improve conductivity. Therefore, the introduction of heteroatoms into carbon of Si/C composite is an important way to adjust the performance of the carbon layer [25,128,132]. Polydopamine is abundant in nitrogen content and functional groups. It is an important precursor for preparation of hybrid materials [133]. Guo et al. [134] reported Si/C composites synthesized by dopamine polymerization and pyrolysis reaction (Fig. 9e–k). Electrochemical characterization showed that the composite had an ICE of 78.1% at 300 mA/g, and high capacity retention (741.2/611.3 mAh/g) after 100 cycles. These were attributed to introduction of N-rich carbon layer. Developing simple preparation methods of even carbon layer is the key to realizing stable cycling of Si/C anodes. Chen et al. [128] proposed a simple surface engineering-assisted strategy. Recycled waste Si powders (RWSi) were functionalized through salinization reaction and uniformly encapsulated by poly (methyl methacrylate) (PMMA), and finally carbonized to form the core-shell structured Si/C composite (m-RWSi@PMMA-C). The m-RWSi@PMMA-C achieved high discharge capacity (3176.2 mAh/g) and CE (75.6%). Sulfur is also a heteroatom that has effect on property of carbon materials, and the specific effect depends on state of sulfur [25,132]. Zhang et al. [135] synthesized Si/(S-doped-carbon nanowire network) by 3,4-ethylenedioxythiophene polymerization and carbonization. The polymerization process used sodium dodecyl sulfate as surfactant, and the carbonization temperature was 800 °C. Since S-doped-carbon nanowires had higher electrical conductivity than poly nanowire, it was beneficial to build strong conductive bridge between Si nanoparticles and provide large electrode-electrolyte interface for fast charge transfer. Therefore, the composite delivered 820 mAh/g capacity after 400 cycles with merely 0.09% capacity fade per cycle. Because most of polymers contain heteroatoms, polymer-derived carbons have better electrical conductivity and have synergistic effect on improving the interfacial charge transfer rate of Si anode [132,134]. In addition, some studies have shown that pitch still has a certain elasticity after carbonization, which can efficaciously limit volume expansion of Si [65]. But polymers, such as petroleum pitch, carry a certain risk of being toxic and carcinogenic. 3.4 Biomass-derived nanostructured carbons Biomass-derived carbons have attracted considerable academic and industrial interest due to their natural abundance, ease of processing, and naturally occurring porous or hierarchical structures [136–139]. Introducing biomass-derived carbons into Si/C composites will lead to development of inexpensive and environmentally friendly preparation methods. Rice husk (RH), a common agricultural waste with high Si content, has been reported as precursor to synthesizing nano Si [140]. Further applications of rice husks on Si-based materials remain to be developed. Chen et al. [141] used rice husk, SiNPs and 1-butyl-3-methylimidazolium acetate (BMIMAcO) as precursors to prepare Si@SiO x @C-800 composite by one-step carbonization at 800 °C. Irregular-shaped carbon blocks and SiO x layers formed by calcination of rice husks at high temperature were coated on SiNPs. Since the effect of SiO x layers to suppress volume expansion and Si–N bonds coupling to enhance Li+ diffusion coefficient, Si@SiO x @C-800 exhibited superior reversible capacity and rate capability. Furthermore, this work adopted an acid- and alkali-free, low-cost method to fabricate Si@SiO x @C-800 composite. Cornstarch is also used as carbon source to prepare low-cost Si/C anodes. Jung et al. [37] synthesized a Si/C hybrid composite, using scalable microemulsion method and heat-treating under C3H6 gas with Si nanoparticles and low-cost cornstarch as biomass precursor. In this work, cornstarch contributed to interfacial stabilization of oil-in-water emulsions and acted as a carbon source (Fig. 10 a). The surface hydrophobicity of Si kept cetyl triethyl ammnonium bromide (CTAB) within oil droplets, so Si clusters were encapsulated by cornstarch. Appropriate strategies resulted in Si/C hybrid composite with high tap density/mass-expandable. When the prepared Si/C hybrid composite was applied to anodes of LIBs, it exhibited high capacity of 1800 mAh/g, and excellent cycle performance with maintaining 80% capacity over 500 cycles (Fig. 10b–d). This was due to the high conductivity and reduced absolute stress/strain of SiNPs encapsulated in double carbon matrix during multiple lithiation/delithiation processes. Biomass is an abundant resource in nature with advantages of pollution-free and low price. Biomass-derived carbon has been synthesized in recent years for gas adsorption [142,143] and energy storage [37,144]. At present, there are relatively few studies on use of biomass as a carbon source for Si composites, mainly because biomass carbon has many defects and unsatisfactory mechanical properties. It can be seen from the above discussion that use of the unique natural structure and composition of biomass to construct Si composites requires in-depth research. 3.5 Carbonaceous gas-derived carbons When synthesizing carbon materials, carbonaceous gas is one of the commonly used carbon sources. Carbonaceous gas-derived carbons have following merits. (1) Synthesis process is clean and pollution-free Application. (2) Prepared carbon layers are controllability and uniformity [58,59,145]. 3.5.1 Acetylene (C2H2) Acetylene (C2H2) is the simplest alkyne, and its pyrolysis reaction is often used to prepare carbon in Si/C composites [36,58]. Qian et al. [36] synthesized a hierarchical structure composed of SiNPs (20 nm) using a solvothermal method, and prepared Si/C composites (Si-20@C) by carbon coating through acetylene pyrolysis (Fig. 11 a). Si-20@C composite and Si-20 showed a capacity retention of 915.8 and 393 mAh/g after 500 cycles at 3.6 A/g (Fig. 11b). Moreover, even at 10.8 A/g, it displayed a charge capacity of 746.2 mAh/g (Fig. 11c). The impressive property of Si-20@C could be ascribed to critical size of component Si nanoparticles and carbon layer coating. 3.5.2 Carbon dioxide (CO2) The application of carbon dioxide (CO2) as carbon source not only has the common advantages of gas carbon sources, but also has following advantages. (1) CO2 as a greenhouse gas needs to develop economical, environmentally friendly and high value-added utilization methods [146–148]. (2) Due to the use of in-situ metal thermal reduction, carbon shell has better homogeneity and electrical conductivity [149,150]. Our group [21] synthesized layer-by-layer Si/C (L-Si/C) at 550, 650, and 750 °C using commercial alloys (CaSi2) and CO2 as precursors, respectively (Fig. 11f). In this process, CaSi2 was surrounded by CO2, and reversibly decomposed into Si and Ca under heating. At an appropriate temperature, Ca reacted with CO2 to form CaCO3, which was also covered by carbon atoms. The CaCO3 was removed with HF solution to obtain L-Si/C. Electrochemical characterizations confirmed that L-Si/C-750 composite exhibited the best cycling stability (capacity retentions of 91.21% after 400 cycles) (Fig. 11d) and rate performance (919.8 mAh/g at 5000 mA/g) (Fig. 11c) among all samples obtained at different temperatures. The tunable carbon layer was advantageous to increase conductivity, avoid accumulation of Si, and build stable SEI for superior structural stability. Besides, the 2D structure was advantageous to boost interfacial charge transfer. In addition, our group [151] also prepared uniform nanoporous Si/C composite anodes by reacting a commercial magnesium silicide alloy (Mg2Si) with carbon dioxide. By adapting the reaction conditions, the degree and thickness of the Si voids and graphitization of carbon layer could be controlled. As LIBs anode, it exhibited impressive cycling stability and rate capability. It is a common method to prepare Si/C composites by CVD method using C2H2 as carbon source. The synthesized carbon layer is uniform and controllable in thickness, and the preparation process is mature. However, CVD equipment is expensive, and gases such as C2H2 are flammable. In addition, recent studies suggest that C2H2-derived carbon has a certain brittleness [65]. Another carbonaceous gas, carbon dioxide (CO2), is a carbon source that has received attention in recent years. The preparation of carbon layers is mainly based on the magnesium thermal reduction reaction between CO2 and active metals [21,146,147,151]. As a greenhouse gas, CO2 has good practical value as a carbon source. However, the process of preparing carbon layers with CO2 as carbon source has certain limitations. Additionally, the mechanical and chemical properties of CO2-derived carbon need to be further explored. 3.6 Others Metal-organic frameworks (MOFs), which are porous coordination polymers consisting of inorganic nodes linked with organic ligands, have been used in various fields, including gas separation, catalysis, and energy storage [152–154]. MOFs-derived carbons are rich in heteroatoms, which have also been recently reported as carbon source for Si/C composites. Wang et al. [155] used self-corrosion reaction of SiAl alloy to synthesize SiAl/Al-MOF core–shell precursor, and obtained porous Si microspheres@C core–shell composites (pSiMS@C) after reasonable annealing and etching. Since the porous Si and core–shell structure can alleviate huge volume change during cycling, pSiMS@C anode showed a reversible capacity of 1027.8 mAh/g after 500 cycles. Su et al. [156] prepared Si@Co-NC composite composed of Si nanoparticle core and N-doped/Co-incorporated carbon shell by carbonization of zeolite imidazolate frameworks (ZIF) and Si nanoparticles. Since doping of N and introduction of Co particles increased electrical conductivity of the carbon shell, and hollow structure could effectively relieve volume change, the Si@Co-NC composite obtained stable cycling performance. Yang et al. [40] constructed Si/C composites (Si NDs ⊂ MDN) with ultrasmall Si nanodots (NDs, ∼3 nm) embedded in MOF-derived nanoreactors through a MOF-derived single-atom catalytic strategy (Fig. 12 a–d). When used as LIBs anodes, Si NDs ⊂ MDN displayed high structural stability, high capacity and excellent rate performance. Concretely, first charge and discharge capacity were ∼1400 and 1592 mAh/g with ICE of ∼87.94%. Si NDs ⊂ MDN anode showed reversible capacity of 1172 mAh/g at a higher rate of 1 A/g after 1000 cycles (Fig. 12e). The excellent property was primarily ascribed to encapsulation of Si NDs in nanopores by porous MDN, which could efficiently accommodate volume expansion of Si NDs. Additionally, interconnected nanopores in the MDN provided continuous channels for fast lithium ions transport. Additionally, Zhang et al. [157] fabricated freestanding Si/C-ZIF-8/CNFs composites through introducing CNFs. Si/C-ZIF-8/CNFs composites exhibited improved electronchemical properties. g-C3N4 is a unique two-dimensional material, which is an N-substituted graphitic framework composed of π-conjugated graphite planes formed by sp 2- hybridization of C and N atoms [158]. Due to tunable band gap and high physicochemical stability of g-C3N4, it has been broadly applied in the field of energy storage [159–161]. Our group [30] synthesized nanoporous Si uniformly coated with N-doped carbon nanosheets frameworks (NPSi@NCNFs) by a one-step, vacuum-assisted reactive carbon coating technique using a mixture of g-C3N4 and Mg2Si alloys as precursors. Porosity of Si, degree of graphitization and N content of carbon shell could be readily adjusted by changing synthesis conditions. The controllable carbon shell was beneficial to improving electronic conductivity and stabilizing SEI. Porous Si with appropriate porosity could further alleviate volume change during cycling. When used as anodes for LIBs, the NPSi@NCNFs composites demonstrated 95.68% capacity retention after 4000 cycles. Some new materials, such as MOF, C3N4, etc. have been used as carbon sources to prepare Si/C composites, which have shown excellent cycle stability through reasonable structural design [30,40,162,163]. However, on account of the complex synthesis process and the lack of large-scale synthesis methods for carbon sources, their further applications are limited. 3.7 Carbon contents in Si/C anodes The carbon contents have an important influence on the capacity of Si/C anodes. To guide the design of Si/C anodes, it is important to summarize the quantification of carbon materials. Thermogravimetric analysis (TGA) is a common method used to measure carbon contents [164]. Our group [30] analyzed carbon contents of NPSi@NCNFs products obtained at 600, 700, and 800 °C in air conditions from 30 to 800 °C through TGA test. Analysis results demonstrated that NPSi@NCNFs-800 had the highest carbon contents. Meanwhile, mass of SiNPs improved with the temperature increased. As a result, TGA is suitable for qualitative analysis of carbon contents. Owing to the existence of silicon oxides and heteroatom in Si/C anodes, TGA does not completely reveal the carbon contents. Shaw et al. [165] used EDS to quantify elements in Si@void@C(N). The contents of C and Si can be obtained from the elemental analysis results of EDS, and the concentration of heteroatoms in carbon layer can be obtained. 3.8 Functions of carbon materials in Si/C anodes 3.8.1 For active materials (1) Promote electrons and ions transport The semiconducting properties of Si give it low electronic and ionic conductivity. The highly conductive carbon layer can effectively promote the electrons and ions transport, thereby improving the fast charging capability of Si anodes [166]. (2) Suppress volume expansion The huge volume of Si lithiation process is an important reason for its electrical contact failure. Studies have shown that the introduction of carbon materials during lithiation can generate an additional compressive stress on Si, buffering the volume change [21,30,31]. (3) Transfer SEI formation sites The formation of SEI is beneficial to preventing the continuous reaction between Si and electrolyte, and also facilitating the transport of Li+ [167]. The stability of SEI is an important factor for the stable cycling of Si-based anodes. However, due to the volume change during lithiation process, Si continuously reacts with the electrolyte to generate a thick SEI, which does not consume a large amount of electrolyte and also affect the interfacial charge transport [50]. Related reports indicate that an efficient carbon layer can transfer the SEI formation sites and form a stable and thin SEI on the carbon layer [45,108,167]. 3.8.2 For electrode structure (1) Conductive additives In electrodes structure, conductive additives can effectively improve the electronic conductivity of electrode [168]. Super P as conductive additive provides almost no specific capacity, which limits the volumetric capacity of electrode [125]. When used carbon materials of Si/C composites as conductive additives, electrodes obtain the strong conductive network and relatively increased capacity. Furthermore, novel carbon materials with high thermal conductivity can improve battery safety caused by heat dissipation [168–170]. (2) Current collectors The current collector is an important component to maintain electrical contact between active material and external circuit. However, large weight of current collector increases the proportion of inactive components, reducing the energy density. In addition, the binding force between current collector and active material is weak, causing loose electrical contact [168]. CNTs, GO and MXene can be assembled into lightweight and free-standing films. In Si/C composites with rational structures, CNTs, GO and MXene act as current collectors, reducing proportion of inactive components [109,171,172]. 4 Interfacial bonding of Si/C anodes The interface between Si and C determines structural stability and interfacial charge transfer ability of Si/C composites, and has impact on cycle life and rate performance of electrode materials. The interface contact between Si and C are mainly divided into physical contact, hydrogen bond and covalent bond. 4.1 Physical contact Physical contact is common in Si/C composites, such as self-supporting core–shell structures, Si-graphite blends, etc. [167,173]. The contact mode and charge transfer of Si and C in Si/C composites bonded by physical contact need to be paid attention. The construction of self-supporting core-shell Si/C composites is one of the important strategies to solve volume expansion and interfacial instability of Si anodes [156]. The self-supporting carbon shell provides expansion space for Si to maintain integrity of electrode. Carbon shell can prevent direct exposure of Si to electrolyte, which is conducive to formation of stable SEI. Carbon shell can also provide necessary transport channels for electrons and lithium ions [174,175]. Point-to-point is a common contact form in core–shell structures. Yu et al. [167] produced double carbon shell-coated Si nanoparticles (DCS-Si) by chemical vapor deposition and magnesium thermal reduction. The inner carbon shell provided limited internal voids, allowing volume change of Si particles within inner carbon shell. Meanwhile, outer carbon shell formed a stable SEI (Fig. 13 a–f). Mi et al. [174] fabricated yolk-shell structured Si@void@C composites using a self-sacrificial template strategy. In this work, polyethyleneimine (PEI) was used to generate void spaces during carbonization without acid or alkali etching. Liu et al. [176] contrasted submicron Si powder with a certain degree of oxidation and commercial soft asphalt (softening point 83 °C, denoted as P1), high-temperature asphalt (softening point 230 °C, denoted as P2) and AP3 asphalt (softening point 350 °C, denoted as P3). The mixture was carbonized and washed with HF solution to obtain Si@void@C composites. The connection between microstructure of carbon shell and electrochemical behavior of Si@void@C was examined by tuning pitch species and heat treatment temperature to ensure robust physical buffer with efficient ion and electron transport paths. Line-to-line is another form of contact. Zhi et al. [177] synthesized a Si/C nanohybrid in which Si nanowires reside in hollow graphite tubes (SiNW-d-GT) (Fig. 13g and h). The line-to-line contact between Si and C provided an efficient channel for electron and lithium ions transport. And built-in void space buffered the volume changes. As a result, the SiNW-d-GT anodes showed great rate capability and cycling stability (Fig. 13i). 4.2 Hydrogen bonds When hydrogen atom forms covalent hydride with atoms with high electronegativity and small radius such as fluorine and oxygen atoms, the hydrogen atom is almost in proton state. It can have an electrostatic attraction with another atom containing a lone pair of electrons, which is called hydrogen bond [178]. Due to its self-healing and deformability, hydrogen bonds have attracted attention in the fields of functional hydrogels and adhesives [179,180]. Introducing hydrogen bonds to the interface of Si/C composites can relieve volume expansion and release stress, thereby improving their cycling stability. Lu et al. [181] used phytic acid to grind the initial silica powder, which not only reduced particle size significantly, but also made irregular edges smooth and rich in hydroxyl groups. Graphene oxide (GO) and acid-treated carbon nanotubes have many –COOH and –OH groups, which could form hydrogen bonds with –OH groups on surface of Si particles (Fig. 14 a). Specifically reflected in the cycling performance, reversible capacity of the Si-based gel was 1085.3 mAh/g after 100 cycles. However, the discharge capacity of Si-PA/GO/CNTs mixture decreased expeditiously, and merely maintained 198.9 mAh/g after 100 cycles (Fig. 14c). The improved cycling performance might be ascribed to fact that 3D porous gel network was conducive to enduring volume change of Si during lithium intercalation process, facilitating transport of electrons and lithium ions (Fig. 14b), and prohibiting agglomeration of Si particles as well. The formation of hydrogen bonds enhanced structural stability and improved diffusion of lithium ions through electrode. In Si/C composites, surfactants are usually used to composite Si particles with negatively charged carbon-based materials such as graphene through hydrogen bonds. Due to the different structures of polymer surfactants, different polymer surfactants have different impacts on cycling performance of Si/graphene anodes. Dai et al. [182] performed ab initio simulations through DFT to elucidate weak interactions between GO and PSS, PDDA, PVP. From the results, it could be seen that both nitrogen and oxygen atoms of PVP formed hydrogen bonds with the hydrogen atoms in graphene oxide functional group, and adsorption energy was as high as 1.58 eV. In contrast, heteroatoms of PSS and PDDA (sulfur atom of PSS, sulfur atom of PDDA, Nitrogen atoms) and graphene oxide had fewer hydrogen bonds and thus weaker interactions, with binding energies of 0.7 and 0.92 eV, respectively. Du et al. [35] synthesized ultrathin Si-NSs with average thickness of less than 2 nm through magnesium thermal reduction of Al2O9Si3 montmorillonite etched by hydrochloric acid, and obtained Si-NSs@rGO nanocomposites by electrostatic assembly of PDDA-Si-NSs and graphene(rGO) (Fig. 14d). The tight assembly of Si-NSs and graphene was beneficial to preventing aggregation of Si-NSs, improving electrical conductivity, and enabling mechanically stable electrodes. When used as anodes for LIBs, the Si-NSs@rGO nanocomposite demonstrated stable cycling performance (1006.1 mAh/g after 1000 cycles) (Fig. 14e) and fairly high rate performance (1727.3 mAh/g at 10 A/g). 4.3 Covalent bonds Covalent bonds are interactions between atoms formed by sharing pairs of electrons. Compared with hydrogen bonding, it has high mechanical strength and stable chemical properties [183–185]. Therefore, it is applied in LIBs wildly, such as construction of artificial SEI [186]. 4.3.1 Si-C covalent bond Chemical properties of Si–C bonds are very stable, and synthesis temperature is generally 1623 K, so it is difficult to introduce Si–C bonds into Si/C composites [187–189]. Since magnesium thermal reduction reaction is exothermic process, the large amount of heat released during replacement process can increase local temperature and form Si–C bonds [149,150]. Gao et al. [185] prepared g-Si/CNTs with strong Si–C covalent bonds from recycled waste glass and commercial CNTs (Fig. 15 a). During magnesiothermic reduction process, the Si–C bonds generated in-situ at interface between Si nanoparticles and CNTs enhanced the interaction between CNTs and Si, improving the interfacial conductivity and structural stability. The g-Si/CNTs anode enabled stable cycling performance. Furthermore, g-Si/CNTs anode also displayed high rate capability (386 mAh/g at 5 A/g) (Fig. 15b). 4.3.2 Si–X–C covalent bond (X = O, N, S) By introducing heteroatoms into carbon materials to build defects, the binding energy between Si and carbon materials can be increased [25,190]. Chen et al. [190] used ultrasonic radiation to uniformly mix SiNP (B60%), S-doped graphene (SG), GO and polyacrylonitrile (PAN) in dimethylformamide (DMF). The mixture casted onto copper foil was dried and heated at 450 °C for 10 min in an inert gas to obtain the SG-Si-PAN composite with covalent bond synergy (Fig. 15f). Through DFT model (Fig. 15g), Si atom had covalent interaction with one sulfur atom and two adjacent carbon atoms in the SG. The binding of Si to SG was stronger than to G because of covalent interaction of Si atoms with sulfur atoms and increase in charge density of defective carbons near sulfur. These indicated that the interaction between Si and SG was covalently synergistic, thereby enhancing property of electrode. The electrode was still able to provide discharge capacity of ∼2350 mAh/cm3 at 100th cycle. The disassembled coin cell that cycled 2275 cycles was further characterized. The cycled Si was confined in folds of SG and encapsulated by c-PAN due to covalent interaction between Si, SG, and N. Due to nanostructure design of electrode and covalent interaction of Si with SG to organize the agglomeration of Si, the location of SiNPs was associated with high sulfur and high carbon regions, which was an important reason for the electrode to maintain stability over 2275 cycles. Yang et al. [191] fabricated mesoporous Si with pore size of 20 nm by electrochemical etching, and then carried out in-situ carbonization in Ar and H2 atmospheres with PAN solution. Dangling bonds on surface of fresh amorphous Si reacted with surrounding –NH bonds to form covalent Si–C bonds. By adjusting the annealing time, SiNC layer was synthesized at mesoporous Si interface. The interface layer could serve as electrolyte barrier layer to establish stable SEI layer. SiNC layer with low Li+ diffusion kinetics and conductive Si nanocrystals formed by self-limited heterogeneous lithiation in-situ were beneficial to preventing anodes breakage. In addition, Si nanocrystals could also realize fast and reversible electrochemical reactions. Polarization potential of carbon-coated MSP cells increased significantly. In detail, the samples annealed in Ar and H2 for 1, 3, and 8 h had polarization potentials of 0.42, 0.36, and 0.54 V at semi-reversible capacities, respectively. Among them, the sample annealed in Ar and H2 for 8 h had a capacity retention of 100% at 400th cycle. The excellent long cycle life is mainly attributed to mesoporous structure and compact SiNC layer with low Li+ diffusion kinetics. High temperature heat treatment could be avoided by introducing active groups, thereby obtaining stable covalent bonds. Chen et al. [192] prepared NH2-terminated Si/GO (Si@NH2/GO) through hydrogen bonding and covalent cross-linking. The Si@NH2 first formed hydrogen and covalent bonds with GO. The Si@NH2/GO composite further formed hydrogen and covalent bonds with sodium alginate to form stable composite anode. The double covalent crosslinking/hydrogen bonding interactions and flexible graphene oxide together yielded a robust networked anode system. When used as anodes for LIBs, Si@NH2/GO electrode has excellent performance, with 1000 mAh/g and close to 100% retention after 400 cycles. Most of covalent bond designs are mainly focused on bonding of Si particles to 2D carbon materials, and therefore contain a limited number of covalent bonds. The low-dimensionalization of Si particles is more conducive to construction of covalent bonds. Wang et al. [193] chemically cut CNTs using atomic oxygen generated by UV-ozone (UVO). Si uniformly nucleated the oxygen-containing parts of CNTs to prepare Si/C composites (f-CNTs@Si). Through chemically tailoring Si/C interface by atomic oxygen alone, cycle time of f-CNTs@Si composites was significantly improved, with an areal capacity closed to 1.61 mAh/cm2 after 500 cycles. Zhi et al. [194] synthesized skin-like two-dimensional covalently bonded Si/C hybrid materials (SF@G) by magnesium reduction and CVD process. As anode for LIBs, the initial Coulombic efficiency of SF@G was 87%. Moreover, stable Coulombic efficiency of SF@G rapidly increased to 99%, which was higher than that of SF@G-HF and SF, indicating interfacial difference between them. SF@G could effectively prevent irreversible lithium consumption and the SEI formation. In addition, SF@G had stable cycling ability and excellent rate capability (812 mAh/g at 20 A/g). It was observed by SEM that SF@G retained the original flower-like structure with thin and smooth interface morphology after 100 cycles. While SF@G-HF was filled with a large amount of rough SEI deposits. The flower-like structure of SF was completely deformed. The interfacial composition of cycled SF@G-HF and SF was Li2CO3, LiF, Li x PF y , Li x PO y F z and R-Si-OR’ by XPS test, while interfacial composition of SF@G was organic species, and ROCOLi, and minor amount of inorganic material. The above results demonstrated that 2D covalent ensemble created strong and efficient contact between Si and conducting medium, enabling fast and stable electrons and ions transport to Si. Moreover, this unique interfacial morphology was beneficial to preventing direct contact between Si and electrolyte, constructing stable SEI, and enabling battery to obtain outstanding cycling ability. In addition, an integrated electrode of Si anode and copper current collector can also be constructed through covalent bonds. Tong et al. [195] synthesized the Si hybridized rGO and double-faced adhesive tape derived carbon composite (Si + rGO@DFAT-C) in-situ by immobilizing the mixed powder of reduced graphene oxide and Si on the copper foil current collector (Fig. 15c). DFAT used as the binder and carbon source. Through pyrolysis, DFAT-C generated SiOC and Si–C chemical bonds between Si and graphene (Fig. 15d), and CuOC chemical bonds between carbon and copper foil (Fig. 15e). This method was conductive to improve integrity and conductivity of electrodes, prevent agglomeration of Si particles, and also establish channels for charge transfer. The Si + rGO@DFAT-C anode demonstrated superior electron stability (968.1 mAh/g after 200 cycles) and high rate capability (1126 mAh/g at 2 A/g). Additionally, DFT calculations further indicated the role of covalent bonds on improvement of electrochemical performance. DOS analysis proved that electrons migrated from SiO x into the carbon structure, resulting in decreased binding energies of Si in the Si and SiO x structures and increased binding energy of carbon. Calculated band information showed that the Fermi level of Si/SiO x was connected to the Fermi level of carbon, and then a dipole layer was formed at the interface. Hybridization shifted the Si 2p and C 1s core lines downward with respect to the upward Fermi level, creating new electronic states for the electron channel due to electric field effects. Above results indicated that chemical bonds generated the electric carriers and form electric field effect to promote electron transport. The electrochemical performance of Si/C composites with different interface bonding are summarized in Supplementary Information Table 1. The Si and C shells in Si/C composites with nanocore-shell structure are point-to-point contact [196,197]. In this way, the minor interface limits transport channels of Li+ and electrons, greatly limiting the rate of charge transport and reaction. Therefore, increasing contact points is important strategy to optimize core–shell structure. The way to increase contact points is to increase the number of cores in nanocore-shell structure [167,198], and expand the dimension of core–shell structure such as line-to-line (2D) [177] contact and face-to-face contact (3D) [22]. The optimized core–shell structure Si/C composites exhibit excellent cycle stability and rate performance. Nevertheless, the synthesis process is complex, involving CVD and strong acid. In addition, a large number of voids will reduce tap density of electrode, which limits their practical application. The hydrogen bond is mainly achieved by introducing groups and surfactants [35,182]. Different surfactants have a great impact on the strength of hydrogen bond [182]. Compared with other interface bonding, introduction method of hydrogen bonds is simple. It does not involve acid, alkali and high temperature, and has good universality. However, the weak bonding force characteristics of hydrogen bonds make improvement of cycle stability of Si/C composites limited. The introduction of covalent bonds often leads to better properties of Si/C composites [185,190,194]. High-strength covalent bonds can ensure effective contact between Si and C during cycling and maintain stable lithium ion and electron transport channels [194]. Due to the difficulty of forming covalent bonds between Si and C, it is necessary to select carbon sources containing heteroatoms such as N, O, S, because carbon containing heteroatoms is more likely to form covalent bonds with Si [190]. Therefore, increasing contact points remains an important strategy for optimizing Si/C composites with covalent bonds. 5 Application of Si/C anodes for other battery systems Carbon-modified Si-based materials have also been used in all-solid-state lithium-ion batteries (ASSLIBs) and sodium-ion batteries (SIBs). 5.1 All-solid-state lithium-ion batteries Si/C composites in liquid batteries have been successfully used in all-solid-state batteries. Lee et al. [199] produced Si/C composites using the pyrolytic carbon of coal-tar pitch as carbon source. Through optimization of Si/C composite anode, ASSLIBs showed a stable 653.5 mAh/g after 100 cycles. This group [200] also prepared Si/C fibers by electrospinning and subsequent heat treatment process using polyacrylonitrile as carbon precursor. ASSLIBs fabricated from Si/C fibers (∼0.1 μm) achieved reversible specific capacities of ∼700 mAh/g after 70 cycles. Optimizing design of Si/C composites to enhance electrons and ions transport was the key to realizing high-performance ASSLIBs. Lee et al. [201] designed a graphite-silicon diffusion-dependent electrode used for ASSLIBs. The optimized electrode (G/SiNPs 90/10, wt%) exhibited remarkable rate capability (2.76 mAh/cm2 at 0.5 C) and cycle ability (72.7% after 200 cycles). In this work, digital twin-driven 3D structures indicated that electrochemical ability of graphite-silicon diffusion-dependent electrode greatly relied on Si particle size. Nanoscale Si appreciably increased the contact area with graphite with identical electrode parameters (1.732 × 10−9 to 5.255 × 10−9 m2) (Fig. 16 a and b). The coverage of graphite by Si nanoparticles and microparticles were 78.2% and 25.8%, respectively. The following electrochemical simulations showed that enlarged contact area through regulating particles size allowed Li+ easily transport to the whole electrode (Fig. 16c and d). However, carbon has high SSA and electronic conductivity, which may promote the decomposition of sulfide [202]. Meng et al. [203] illustrated the effects of carbon additives on SSE decomposition. The voltage profiles showed that cell with 20 wt% carbon occurred extensive SSE electrochemical decomposition from 2.5 to 3.5 V. And the main decomposition product was Li2S. The above discussions show that if Si/C anodes are used in ASSLIBs with sulfide-based SSEs, they need to be modified. SSEs decomposition induced by carbon additives mainly occurs in ASSLIBs with sulfide-based SSEs on account of its narrow electrochemical stability window [203–205]. Polymer SSEs have the advantages of interfacial contact, fabrication and stability. Pairing Si/C composites and polymer SSEs is an effective approach to achieved stable operation of Si/C composites in ASSLIBs. Huang et al. [206] prepared 3D porous composite polymer electrolytes using PVDF, PVDF-HFP, LiTFSI, Li7La3Zr2O12 (LLZO), and propylene carbonate (PC). When micro-sized Si@Li3PO4@C used as anode, the full cell exhibited high capacity retention (98.5% after 100 cycles) and superior rate performance (92.5 mAh/g at 2.0 A/g). Zhao et al. [207] reported a high-capacity ASSLIB with Si@MOF anode and fiber-supported PEO/garnet composite (PPG) electrolyte (Fig. 16e–g). In this anode, MOF-derived carbon was able to suppress volume change and promote charge transfer. The full cell with LiFePO4 (LFP) cathode showed high initial discharge capacity (135 mAh/g at 0.5 C) and capacity retention (73.1% after 500 cycles) at 60 °C (Fig. 16h and i). 5.2 Sodium-ion batteries The theoretical specific capacity of Si for sodium storage is 954 mAh/g, and NaSi phase is formed at this stage [208]. However, due to the poor sodium diffusion kinetics and positive binding energy in the adsorption process of crystalline Si, it is difficult for crystalline Si to intercalate sodium [209]. As a result, the Si-based materials used for sodium storage are mainly Si compounds and amorphous Si [210]. Yu et al. [211] prepared SiP2/C composite anode through simple ball milling method. The capacity retention of SiP2/C exceeded 80% for 500 cycles. Excellent performance attributed to conductive carbon framework for improved electrode conductivity and structural compatibility. 6 Summary and perspectives This review first reviews two interfacial reactions of Si anodes, alloying and SEI formation. And we focus on various carbon sources in Si/C composites, such as traditional carbon sources (graphite, etc.), and novel carbon sources (MXene and graphene, etc.). The merits and demerits of each type of carbon source are summarized. In addition, this paper also pays attention to interfacial bonding of Si/C composites, and effect of each interfacial bonding on the performance. As shown in Fig. 17 , Commercialization of Si/C anodes requires addressing some issues such as tap density, preparation methods of carbon materials, structural and interfacial stability. 6.1 Developing novel carbon sources and synthesis methods There are various carbon sources for Si/C composites. In addition to traditional carbon sources such as graphite [32], biomass-derived carbon [141], C2H2-derived carbon [59], and pitch-derived carbon [38], new carbon sources such as graphene [88], graphdiyne [34], MXene [109], CO2 [21] and MOFs-derived carbon [40] have also received attention. The properties of carbon materials have great impact on electrochemical performance of Si/C composites. When choosing a carbon source, consideration should be given to mechanical properties, electrical conductivity, etc. as well as safety and sustainability. Additionally, the synthesis temperature of carbon should be further reduced. 6.2 Balancing energy density and cycle life Introduction of carbon materials greatly improves the cycle stability of Si/C composites, but tends to reduce charge-discharge capacity of electrodes, which is detrimental to energy density of LIBs [25,212]. Consequently, introduction of carbon materials requires a compact design to improve the energy density of Si/C composites. In addition, under premise of ensuring stable cycle stability, Si content should be increased as much as possible. 6.3 Construction and understanding of interface bonding The interface between Si and C requires attention. Currently, the reported interfacial bonding of Si and C include physical contact [167], hydrogen bonds [35], Si–C and Si–X–C covalent bonds [185,190]. Each interfacial bonding has its own merits and demerits. For example, the introduction methods of physical contact and hydrogen bonds are simple, but the bonding effect is weak [194]. Covalent bonds have high mechanical properties, but often need to be introduced at high temperature [185,193,195]. In addition, there are fewer studies on the interface between Si and C, and more synthetic methods and characterization techniques for stable interfacial bonding need to be developed. 6.4 Combining advanced technology to understand structure–activity relationships In recent years, artificial intelligence and simulation have received extensive attention in the field of materials science [213,214]. With the aid of advanced technology, the structure-activity relationship of Si/C anodes can be deeply understood. In addition, the failure mode of Si/C composites needs further research to provide reference for design of carbon material thickness, strength and voids. Besides, the effects of structure and composition of carbon layer on SEI formation should further be studied using in-situ testing technology. For example, composition and structural evolution of SEI are researched by in-situ XPS and TEM, respectively. 6.5 Expanding application of Si/C anodes in non-lithium-ion batteries Si has been used as anode for Na+ and K+ storage by regulating of crystal structure [215,216]. However, Si/C anodes have not yet been used in Na+ and K+ storage. With the research of novel energy storage systems, the application of Si/C anodes in Na+/K+ storage and even Mg2+/Ca2+storage should be further studied. 6.6 Studying safe and efficient prelithiation methods ICE of Si/C anodes is about 85%, which lower than the ICE commercial graphite anodes. Therefore, Si/C anodes need to be prelithiated before assembling batteries to improve the ICE. Many prelithiation methods have been reported, however, safe, efficient, and large-scale prelithiation methods remain a key issue in the practical process of Si/C anodes. 6.7 Performance testing of practical applications of Si/C anodes Rationally designed Si/C anodes have achieved stable cycling performance, but most of the tests are only carried out in coin cells, and pouch cells that are closer to practical applications have not been assembled. In addition, laws about low temperature electrochemical performance of Si/C anodes should be further tested and clarified. 6.8 Elevating safety of batteries The main research of Si is to improve its cycle stability, so the Si/C anodes have mainly focused on its own performance optimization since 1995, and did not involve safety issues. In the future, research on non-flammable electrolytes and solid-state electrolytes matching Si/C anodes should be carried out. His research focuses on silicon-based anodes for lithium-ion battery. Yongling An is a PhD student under the supervision of Professor Jinkui Feng at Shandong University. His current research focuses on high energy density and high safety battery systems. He has published in Mater. Today, Adv. Funct. Mater., Nano Today, Nano energy, ACS Nano, Energy Storage Mater., etc. Chengkai Liu is a Master student under the supervision of Professor Jinkui Feng at Shandong University. He received his bachelor’s degree from Sichuan University. His current research focuses on hydrogel electrolyte for zinc-ion battery. He has published in Chem. Eng. J. Hengtao Shen is a Master student under the supervision of Professor Jinkui Feng at Shandong University. He received his B. Eng degree from University of Jinan. His current research focuses on two-dimensional materials for energy storage. Jinkui Feng is currently a professor at Shandong University in China. He also conducted research on solid state batteries as a research fellow at National University of Singapore between 2008 and 2011. He received his B.S. (2003) in physical chemistry and Ph.D. (2008) in electrochemistry at Wuhan University, China. His current research interests are focused on high energy density electrode materials, non-flammable electrolytes and MXenes for sustainable energy storage. He published over 200 refereed papers in Adv. Mater., Energy Environ. Sci., Adv. Energy Mater., Nano Today, Nano Energy, ACS Nano., Energy Storage. Mater., etc.

coredata.dc:description: Silicon (Si) has been studied as a promising alloying type anode for lithium-ion batteries due to its high specific capacity, low operating potential and abundant resources. Nevertheless, huge volume expansion during alloying/dealloying processes and low electronic conductivity of Si anodes restrict their electrochemical performance. Thus, carbon (C) materials with special physical and chemical properties are applied in Si anodes to effectively solve these problems. This review focuses on current status in the exploration of Si/C anodes, including the lithiation mechanism and solid electrolyte interface formation, various carbon sources in Si/C anodes, such as traditional carbon sources (graphite, pitch, biomass), and novel carbon sources (MXene, graphene, MOFs-derived carbon, graphdiyne, etc.), as well as interfacial bonding modes of Si and C in the Si/C anodes. Finally, we summarize and prospect the selection of carbonaceous materials, structural design and interface control of Si/C anodes, and application of Si/C anodes in all-solid-state lithium-ion batteries and sodium-ion batteries et al. This review will help researchers in the design of novel Si/C anodes for rechargeable batteries.
